content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Recycling of Fibrous Textile and Carpet Waste Conference (7th - 2002)</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/10599" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>May 13-14, 2002, Dalton, Georgia</subtitle> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/10599</id> <updated>2015-03-12T15:16:30Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-12T15:16:30Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Georgia Tech and Dalton State College's CARPET Research Facilities and Activities</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11094" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Cook, Fred L.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11094</id> <updated>2013-11-18T19:14:07Z</updated> <published>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Georgia Tech and Dalton State College's CARPET Research Facilities and Activities Cook, Fred L. CARPET (Center And Research Program in Engineered Tufts) is an endowed program established by the carpet and allied industries to support research related to the floorcoverings sector. It provides a link between academic institutions and the carpet industry to address both technical and educational issues. Fundamental research laboratories will be located at GIT in Atlanta, and pilot processing/testing laboratories are being set up at the DSC Dalton site. CARPET's missions as related to the sustainability of the carpet industry and products will be discussed. </summary> <dc:date>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Cook, Fred L.</dc:creator> <dc:description>CARPET (Center And Research Program in Engineered Tufts) is an endowed program established by the carpet and allied industries to support research related to the floorcoverings sector. It provides a link between academic institutions and the carpet industry to address both technical and educational issues. Fundamental research laboratories will be located at GIT in Atlanta, and pilot processing/testing laboratories are being set up at the DSC Dalton site. CARPET's missions as related to the sustainability of the carpet industry and products will be discussed.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Update on Carpet As an Alternative Fuel for Cement Kilns</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11093" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Realff, Matthew J.</name> </author> <author> <name>Clark, James L.</name> </author> <author> <name>Cook, Fred L.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11093</id> <updated>2013-11-18T19:02:54Z</updated> <published>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Update on Carpet As an Alternative Fuel for Cement Kilns Realff, Matthew J.; Clark, James L.; Cook, Fred L. Cement kilns have a tremendous appetite for energy. Carpet has a relatively high value of energy content due to its high fraction of polymer material, and its calcium carbonate filler is a feed for cement kilns. This talk will focus on the progress that has been made towards solving the technical and economic issues surrounding the use of carpet as fuel for cement kilns as part of a regional system for recycling carpet. </summary> <dc:date>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Realff, Matthew J.</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Clark, James L.</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Cook, Fred L.</dc:creator> <dc:description>Cement kilns have a tremendous appetite for energy. Carpet has a relatively high value of energy content due to its high fraction of polymer material, and its calcium carbonate filler is a feed for cement kilns. This talk will focus on the progress that has been made towards solving the technical and economic issues surrounding the use of carpet as fuel for cement kilns as part of a regional system for recycling carpet.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Nyloboard Building Materials</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11092" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Bacon, Forrest</name> </author> <author> <name>Holland, Wendell</name> </author> <author> <name>Weitz, Jack</name> </author> <author> <name>Kelly, Patrick</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11092</id> <updated>2013-11-18T19:15:43Z</updated> <published>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Nyloboard Building Materials Bacon, Forrest; Holland, Wendell; Weitz, Jack; Kelly, Patrick Three new categories of building materials are discussed, all made from needle-punched mats obtained from shredded carpet: (1) "Nyloprime" is made with a two-component adhesive mixture that undergoes foaming reaction to drive the liquid through the dense fiber mat; this material can create a wood-like material in sheets, comparable to plywood or oriented strand board; (2) "Nyloflex" uses heat to soften low-melt polymers such as polypropylene, into a leather-like material; and (3) "Nyloplate" uses resins or heated compression of Nyloboard, to create a harder material that approaches a ceramic in its traits. All three forms offer several major advantages over wood products (including waterproof, bug-proof, and high strength), and can be made by placing a single additional machine at the end of a needle-punch line. </summary> <dc:date>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Bacon, Forrest</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Holland, Wendell</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Weitz, Jack</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Kelly, Patrick</dc:creator> <dc:description>Three new categories of building materials are discussed, all made from needle-punched mats obtained from shredded carpet: (1) "Nyloprime" is made with a two-component adhesive mixture that undergoes foaming reaction to drive the liquid through the dense fiber mat; this material can create a wood-like material in sheets, comparable to plywood or oriented strand board; (2) "Nyloflex" uses heat to soften low-melt polymers such as polypropylene, into a leather-like material; and (3) "Nyloplate" uses resins or heated compression of Nyloboard, to create a harder material that approaches a ceramic in its traits. All three forms offer several major advantages over wood products (including waterproof, bug-proof, and high strength), and can be made by placing a single additional machine at the end of a needle-punch line.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>GeoHay Products from Carpet Waste</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11091" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Weitz, Jack</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/11091</id> <updated>2013-11-18T19:16:57Z</updated> <published>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">GeoHay Products from Carpet Waste Weitz, Jack GeoHay\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd erosion and sediment control products are made from recycled fibers. This talk discusses their characteristics in comparison with traditional products. </summary> <dc:date>2002-05-13T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Weitz, Jack</dc:creator> <dc:description>GeoHay\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd erosion and sediment control products are made from recycled fibers. This talk discusses their characteristics in comparison with traditional products.</dc:description> </entry> </feed>
